Outlook

The chairman of Wetherspoon, Tim Martin, said:

"The main issue for shareholders, which dominates debate, relates to the nature of the UK's post-Brexit relationship with the EU.

"The dichotomy between a 'no-deal' Brexit and a 'deal', as it is often portrayed in the media, politics and business, is highly misleading. The term no-deal really means 'multi-deal' - a multitude of deals agreed between individuals, businesses, governments and other organisations.

In contrast the term 'deal' refers to a 'mono-deal' - a single overarching agreement, which aims to govern the entire relationship between the UK and the EU.

"In reality, a multi-deal Brexit (ie no-deal) is already proceeding at pace. Jean Marc Puissesseau, the boss of the port of Calais, has said "there will not be any delay" in Calais (appendix 1). Ryanair has said that fears about planes not flying post-Brexit "is no longer a risk" (appendix 2). British Airways agrees.

BE11:12am

Strong sales performance in pre-close statement. LFL sales growth in Q4 to date are +6.9% (10 weeks to 7th July). There have been 5 openings year to date, with 9 pubs closed. The company state there is no change to expectations for FY19. Freehold reversions are disclosed as £71m in the year, and £5m of shares were bought back, driving year-end Net Debt expectations of £745m. In the Q3 19 statement, these numbers were the same for reversions, no buybacks had happened, and Net Debt expectations for FY19 were accordingly £5m lower at £740m. LFL comps from the same period last year were +5.2%. This is another very strong sales performance from the company, and we note that there are no signs of weather weakness seen elsewhere in the sector. We would always consider JDW to be insulated from weather variations, given fewer outdoor areas, but note that Young’s and Greene King have reported weaker trading in recent months.

red @Excel Developerto rejoin the eu, you have to now. and so u will.
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Valuation: FY20E PE: 17.1x, EV/EBITDA: 9.3x, Equity FCF yield (pre new pubs/reversions). Overall, we believe that the company has “under-earned” this year relatively to what they could theoretically have achieved in the short term given material wage increases and higher repairs spending. This is classic Wetherspoon – invest when the going is good, so that the estate is well invested ahead of periods of weaker performance.

red but first brexit. thats the first step.
BE11:13am

We believe that last point on repairs / maintenance capex is crucial. Investors and analysts often focus on PE multiples or FCF relative to peers, but this often ignores how much investment is baked into these numbers. JDW could easily lower either repairs spending or maintenance capex, and assuming a constant FCF yield one could conclude the value of the company is higher. Some companies may be tempted to “enjoy” operational gearing benefits from strong sales growth, but this is not the case with Wetherspoon, who appear relaxed about generating a year of weaker profits if it is for the long term good of the business. We consider JDW’s FCF (pre new pub capex) as the best metric on which to value the business, as unlike most peers, FCF is materially higher than net income. Ie, we believe that P&L earnings are very prudent, mainly due to a ‘high’ depreciation charge vs maintenance capex. The fact that the shares are around the all-time high today suggests that investors are, overall, happy to look through volatility in year-to-year earnings in favour of building perpetuity value in the business. Wetherspoon’s long-term approach (look after customers, look after staff) has paid off for shareholders and we reiterate our OW rating.

JDW is trading on peak earnings at peak valuation of 9.8x EV/EBITDA 12m
forward, two standard deviations higher than the LT average of 7.9x. This gives cause for share price concern when there are underlying forecast downgrades and ROCE is at 10-year lows. Share buybacks, for so long propping up EPS, seemed to be off the agenda, but returned in June (£5.4m). If these recede we think investor attention will refocus on long-term margin erosion and profits going backwards this year. We are fans of the business, but not of the shares at this premium valuation. We reiterate our SELL rating and 1,100p target price based on a de-rating to more comfortable levels

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Not much on the call that could support weak share price today but -15% intra day share price move appears to be at the extreme end relative to the downgrades and factoring in low valuations. On the call, the message on European outlook was subdued with growth slowing mainly in June. APAC was impacted by tariff disputes with growth in China slowing. In Australia, the slowdown is more due to internal issues rather than external, but we would flag the weakening trends in SEEK data and therefore recovery appears unlikely to us. In the UK continued Brexit uncertainty means candidate and client's confidence is low, although once there is some clarity it should result in churn. Management remains committed to return excess cash (anything above £50m) to shareholders irrespective of the direction of organic growth as working capital generation is counter cyclical. On our estimates Page offers c.3% core dividend yield with potential of 5-6% special dividends.

BE11:22am

Downgrade to Neutral after re-rating, with risks well-spread
As outright recession concerns have eased this year Hays' shares have re-rated c.15% from trough levels to an EV/GP of 1.8x. Although this is still below LT average of 2.1x we believe it now appropriately captures some near-term risks vs. long-term upside. Hays remains ‘best in class’ within the staffing sector in our view, but as current indicators suggest that growth is likely to remain muted (3-4%) over the next 6 months we believe risk/reward looks fairly balanced. We reduce our forecasts by 5-6% for outer years, reduce out price target to 165p and downgrade to Neutral.
Risks have eased in Australia but might be rising elsewhere
Growth momentum has generally been weakening for Hays since 1Q19 (9% to UBSe 4Q19: 2%). Recent election results in Australia might have reduced downside risks there and hence 4Q19 could mark the trough for weakening momentum (UBSe 1% growth vs. 7% 1Q). Against this, our economists recently noted growth weakness is starting to hit the German labour market with unemployment rising in 22% of all districts. Hays' structural positioning in Germany means that outperformance is still likely but a weakening market backdrop is likely to cap off any hopes for a marked acceleration over the next 6 months. Overall, we forecast Hays to report c2% growth in 4Q19 and 4% in FY20 (vs. +6% previously).

Upaswellasdown @ excel - I understand yield to convention as catch all for "lower of yield to maturity or, if there is an issuer option to call, yield to worst"
BE11:22am

Long-term upside still significant but likely to take a backseat for now
Hays is in year 2 of its latest programme which sees the company targeting EBITA of £300-450m by FY22 (vs. a base of £246m in FY19E). The mid-point could see a c.40% profit uplift from today and support valuation levels closer to 220p. Long-term targets in an inherently macro sensitive industry can be difficult to assess but in Hay's case the majority of the profit progress is expected to be underpinned by the structural story in Germany. Any recovery here would likely reinstall hopes that the mid-point can be achieved. However, a recession here would likely see a downside scenario of 125p.
Valuation: EV/GP of 1.8x vs. LT average of 2.1
Hays currently trades on an EV/GP of 1.8x vs. an historical average of 2.1x. We reduce our price target to 165p which is based on a target multiple EV/GP multiple of 1.9x (driven by still a 50:50 weighting of peak/trough historic multiples).

BE11:28am

Micro Focus reported revenues of $1,657m for fiscal H1 ended April
2019, a decline of 5.3% cc, which was slightly below consensus but in
line with company guidance of -4% to -6%. Adjusted EBITDA of
$662m grew 1.8% and beat consensus by 1%, and the EBITDA margin
increased 2.8ppt to 40.0% cc, driven by continued cost management
actions related to the integration program. Given the ~50% share price
appreciation YTD (pre-results), positioning had turned incrementally
more positive on MCRO with the market expecting more than an inline
result. Consistent with the performance at the full year results, the
issues seen in FY18 appear to have further normalized, with MCRO on
a better track – an improving margin and better cash performance (FCF
of $430m up 102% yoy helped by WC) and a clear policy around
capital allocation (e.g. share buybacks and return of value delivered in
1H’19). That said, we still think it may require further large scale M&A
to reach the 15-20% target for mid-term total shareholder returns, and
investors may be waiting until the back-end of FY20 for that to happen.

Ghazali @Tom been supporting the Kiwis ever since PK needed someone to do us a favour. which never works.....also, Indians are overrated I think.
red either way, while they may want to diversify, they are still reliant on china in a large way for now.
BE11:29am

As is Credit Suisse.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Little to offer comfort: Micro Focus has reported interim 1H19 results that
offer limited comfort that revenue trends can improve materially. We continue to believe that Micro Focus should be seen as a company capable of -3 to -5% revenue growth, and the only way to respond to top-line pressure is by
restructuring the cost base. We believe this restructuring drag should be
factored into cash flow expectations, leaving the shares on a FY20E uFCF
yield of 7.4%. Consistent with our comments 12 months ago, A vast
valuation?, we think it is unusual for Micro Focus – a business in decline – to be trading on the same valuation as Avast – a business delivering high-singledigit growth. Hence we reiterate our Underperform, although we nudge our TP higher to 1387p (from 1340p) as we move 1H19 forecasts to actuals.

Tom Dalgleish @Red around that number
BE11:29am

Key issues: Management at Micro Focus is normally known for strong
execution. However, one feature of the 1H results is an 11% decline in
licences, due to what management describes as execution issues in the
Security segment. Management highlights churn in the sales force, but for a company that is focussed on cost disruption, we think these business
disruptions are an inherent risk, similar to the loss of the Host Connectivity sales team in FY17. We think it is worthwhile to step back and consider the two-year trends: Over the last 2 years, by our estimates, revenues have
fallen $283m, at a CAGR of -7.6%, while costs have been cut by $327m in
order to grow EBITDA by 3.5% pa. We do not believe this magnitude of cost cuts is a sustainable driver of EBITDA and it highlights the medium-term challenges to the overall business outlook of Micro Focus.

Have a block of text from Morgan Stanley.

BE11:37am

PBT ahead, net debt better. Barratt reported 17,856 completions, including JVs, up 1.6% in the year (FY18 17,579), a modest improvement vs. its FY18 growth rate (+1.1%), with wholly owned completions up 2.6% at 17,111. ASPs were down 5% (FY18: +5.0%), reflecting changes in mix. Its sales rate was 0.7 private reservations per active outlet per week (FY18: 0.72). PBT is expected to be around £910m, ahead of market expectations (MS: £878m, consensus: £882m), driven by "continued strong progress from margin initiatives, a strong close to the year, and additional contribution from joint ventures". JV profits were £35m (MSe: £25m) Net cash was £765m, ahead of consensus: £710m. Order book – higher volumes. The group's forward sales (including JVs) were up £2.6bn, up 20% year on year (3Q: +2.4%, 1H: +7%, FY18: +11%). Volumes grew 4%. The higher forward sales figure was driven by affordable (sales volume up 37%), and JV's up 101%, with the private wholly owned order book down 2%. Still confident outlook. The group said it "is making good progress against its medium term targets. Our operational improvement underpin our land acquisition at a minimum of 23% gross margin [and minimum 25% ROCE]. We have delivered incremental underlying operating margin improvements of around 70bps this year driven mainly by our margin initiatives." The group has reiterated its 3-5% medium-term volume guidance.Investment recap: a self-help story on margins, at a reasonable valuation. Barratt remains the cheapest of the pan-UK volume housebuilders we cover, on book value measures, trading on 1.4x TBV. Others look cheaper on P/E (Barratt: c.8.5x, Persimmon: 7x, Taylor Wimpey: 8x) 2019 P/E, but Barratt has better earnings momentum and offers more room than peers to improve margins and returns, in our view – hence our Overweight rating. Its 3-5% medium-term volume growth guidance is unchanged; which makes our forecasts, which assume 2% volume declines in FYJun20 and a 6% EPS decline, look conservative. Assuming 3-5% volume growth as guided, house price growth at inflation could drive an EPS in the mid-70s, leaving room for upgrades (FYJun20 consensus: 70p MSe: 65.1p)

11:37 am
BE11:38am

And Peel Hunt.

BE11:38am

A solid H2 combined with a better margin performance results in
us tweaking forecasts up 2% for FY19 with a similar rise likely
for FY20-21. Market activity remains robust with no signs of
sales drop off. The group’s margin story has been a key
differentiator over the last 6-12 months especially as others have
been hit by quality and leasehold concerns. While a chunk of the
value gap has now been closed, Barratt remains a well-run
business.

SoS javid now 5/2 on for next chancellor - what would be his policy for government hosepipe?
marktime Nevertheless impressive that Barratt can be so detailed in its year end update within 10 days
BE11:39am

Volumes and ASP are roughly in line with expectations but margins have moved up to 18.9% for the full year compared with 17.7% last year. The 120bp improvement has come from better land buying, new product ranges, other selfhelp measures and one-off features including a commercial property disposal and impairment write back.
The balance sheet is in good shape with net cash of £765m, c£60-70m
better than expected due to income from JVs and timing of land spend.
Land creditors have edged lower while overall land purchases are marginally ahead of consumption.
Build costs still reported at 3-4%. No change to capital return policy and forward sales are up c13% on a wholly owned basis while sales rates of 0.7 have remained similar to last year's healthy level of 0.72.
Forecasts. Overall we see modest upgrades (£10-20m) on the back of the better margin while we still expect the group to post modest volume growth in FY20-21.
Performance & Valuation. The shares have been the best performers among the big three housebuilders ytd with a rise of 25% compared with +16% for TW and -3% for Persimmon. The sector is up 10% ytd. In valuation terms, the shares are trading on a P/NAV of 1.4x for CY19 and 1.3x for CY20, bang in line with the sector average.

BE11:48am

Following a challenging 2018, we believe Playtech’s B2B business has
stabilized with ex-Asia revenue displaying an encouraging trend. The
transformational acquisition of Snaitech, a B2C business, in 2018
opens up a new growth avenue and we see margin upside in both B2B
and B2C in the medium term. Playtech is well placed to meet
guidance for FY19E, which we think will represent a trough in
terms of organic growth, margin and cash flow. Beyond FY19E, we
expect broad-based growth across B2B and B2C. The overall business
has de-risked, in our view, making the current valuation compelling.
We initiate at Overweight, with a December 2020 price target of 603p,
derived from the equal-weighted blend of DCF, peer multiple and
SOTP valuation methodologies.

Kiwi-juice Zunum Aero, start-up trying to make a hybrid plane running out of cash. Is this the beginning of the end of retarded VC-based start-ups?

red @Tom Dalgleishyup same here. where land is a plenty. but the cities are log jammed
11:49 am
BE11:50am

... so even if the questionable Asian business disappears entirely, it's not a disaster because Playtech would become a normal sort of software company with a normal sort of valuation. That's the argument.

Tom Dalgleish India 24/4
BE11:50am

Playtech can deliver sustainable organic growth. Core (ex-Asia)
B2B gaming revenue momentum appears robust. Organic growth has
been weak historically (LSD FY09-FY17), but we calculate that it
was ~+3%/~+7% in FY17/FY18, albeit cooling to ~+5% in H218
from ~+9% in H118. Structurally, Playtech’s platform represents a
defensible competitive advantage that we believe is practically
impossible to replicate. While we anticipate an organic B2B decline
in FY19E, we assume +4% CAGR thereafter. Snaitech (B2C) is
well-placed for sustained structural growth (~+4%). Italy online
gaming penetration is poised to accelerate and presents the

Here's Nomura's playbook for the evening:

11:56 am
BE11:56am

What Powell has to say will presumably have a major impact on investors' risk appetite one way or the other, and will likely be a key determinant of near-term trends in global share prices and interest rates. This is especially true in that the surprisingly strong US jobs data released on 5 July has raised doubts in the market as to whether the Fed's policy interest rate will indeed be lowered in July. The doubts over the likelihood of a rate cut have in turn caused global stock markets to turn sluggish. Frankly, we think it is impossible to forecast with any precision what Powell might say and how markets might respond, as investors could react in unexpected ways. This is true not only of short-term market participants but also of longer-term investors that fall outside the scope of our monitoring. Rather than offering a bold prediction, we limit ourselves to three scenarios (below), based on the present market positioning of speculative traders and historical market patterns.

BE11:57am

1) Powell all but confirms that a rate cut is coming in July: This would be a
straightforward positive surprise that we think would help keep the liquidity-driven market going, pushing US interest rates down while lifting US stocks. This would be a favorable outcome for CTAs' positions in US stocks and US bonds, and we would therefore expect a pick-up in systematic buying of US equities and a resumption of US bond purchases. In addition, we would expect the stock market bulls to gain the upper hand over the bears in this scenario if the the VIX were to hold below 14.

red @Natelypassing trend imo. destroyed by men with beards touching on middle age
BE11:57am

2) Powell demurs on a July rate cut but expresses a strong reflationist
commitment to letting risk asset prices rise to the point of overheating in the near term: Shock therapy of this sort would probably foster a risk-on mood. We think the immediate effect would be a drop in share prices (a rise in the VIX) and a rise in US interest rates. However, we would expect the S&P 500 stay above 2,935 and would expect the VIX to fall back below 14 after the initial spike. We think CTAs would keep up their stock buying in this scenario, although it is a close call. On the other hand, we would expect 10yr UST yields to break above 2.07%, and would therefore expect CTAs to start exiting long positions in US bonds. Risk-parity funds would presumably engage in some portfolio rebalancing by selling bonds and buying stocks. Ultimately, we would expect both US interest rates and US stocks to rise under this scenario.

Nately @red - touching a much younger woman too. Enough to distract anyone.
red so nomura sits on fences and has one leg either side. but sensible yes.
11:57 am
BE11:58am

3) Powell demurs on a July rate cut and gives an equivocal take on reflation: Short-term traders would probably not like this. Ultra-short-term traders in particular would probably rush to close out long positions in US stocks and US bonds. The S&P 500 could well slide below 2,935 in this scenario, in which case CTAs would be forced to start liquidating long positions in equities. US interest rates would be caught in a tug-of-war between the risk-off mood in the stock market and the dropoff in expectations for a rate cut, but if 10yr UST yields were to break above 2.07%, CTAs would in all likelihood start closing out long positions in US bond futures. In this scenario, then, we would expect interest rates to rise and stocks to fall, and see a risk that CTAs and risk-parity funds alike would take the protective step of reducing their portfolio leverage.

BE11:58am

Action starts at 10am EST, 4pm GMT.

A strong policy response is necessary to guard against risks of a further, sharper loss of economic momentum. Weak incoming data, lingering trade tensions, and preventing both financial conditions from tightening and a non-linear adverse impact on growth are key reasons for a front-loaded adjustment Key points The global economy has lost significant momentum in the past 12 months and trade tensions linger. This is now filtering through more prominently to the US economy. Risks to the outlook remain skewed to the downside. A non-linear impact to growth could materialize if financial conditions tighten, bringing corporate credit risks to the fore. We therefore see a need to act decisively to protect against uncertainty and downside risks. Hence, we continue to expect a quick and front-loaded adjustment (i.e., 50bps cut) by the Fed in July

BE12:05pm

FY19 PBT at the bottom of the guided range. The company today reported FY19 PBT of £41.9m, towards the bottom of the recently guided range [£41.3-48.6m] and in line with our expectations [Stifel: £41.3m]. This includes an £11.1m credit related to the utilisation of the onerous lease provision. The full-year statutory loss before tax of £85.4m, as a result of the non-cash onerous lease and impairment charges of £129.5m, has impacted circa half of the owned retail estate as a result of decreasing store revenues and the cautious recovery plan. Net cash generated from operating activities £35.9m, down 55% YoY. A final dividend will be paid (2.2p), resulting in a total dividend of 11.5p.

BE12:06pm

Outlook. Management admits that the "issues in the business will not be resolved overnight. The team is working hard to revive the brand and early initiatives are gaining some traction". FY20 guidance. Given the scale of the trading downturn in FY19 and the lead times required to rectify the product range and proposition, management views FY20 as a year of reset. FY20 revenues are expected to decline (in line with our expectations at -2%), as the company rebalances promotional activity and strengthens the brand.
What to expect today. At today's presentation, we expect the focus to be on products, in particular short lead-time products and entry into new categories, and on store experience, working with landlords, seen as partners. It will be interesting to hear how Superdry broadens its demographics and what the next steps will be for the brand.

Clearance on secondary channels should help to restore brand equity. One of the priorities of the founder has been to reduce the blank discounting approach adopted by the previous management. Despite a high level of stock to clear, Dunkerton seems to have opted for a smarter way by clearing stock on secondary channels (i.e. eBay and outlets). We think this is essential to restore the brand equity of Superdry and re-ignite sales growth, as heavily discounting in own stores tends to cannibalise full price sales Recent board appointments should increase confidence in the company. Superdry recently appointed Helen Weir, former M&S CFO, and Alastair Miller, former New Look Group CFO, as Senior Independent Director and Chair of the Audit Committee, respectively. These appointments should restore investors' trust in the company's financial reporting, after the recent FX contract-related losses and repeated profit warnings.
Valuation. The shares are down 4% at market open this morning. The stock trades at 13.6x 2019 cal. P/E, roughly in line with the sector (excl. ASOS and boohoo), based on new expected estimates (underl. FY20 PBT expected to be between £30-35m, excl. credit related to the utilisation of the onerous lease provision). Management is well aware of external environment challenges but remains confident that the brand will bounce back.
